title: 106_hr1942
content:
There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so I will summarize the curr_chunk as follows:

"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." The Congress finds that free trade agreements improve income and prosperity by increasing competition, reducing costs, and promoting economic growth. APEC member economies aim for free and open trade by 2020 for developing countries and 2010 for developed countries, leading to new trade opportunities and stability by reducing tariffs and nontariff barriers. Continued economic growth in the Pacific Rim region is crucial for the United States due to the reduction of trade barriers. The financial crisis in Asia has disrupted US export growth, highlighting the importance of free trade agreements amidst global economic pressures. During the years 1989-1997, free trade agreement negotiations were crucial for the United States amidst global economic pressures. Countries like New Zealand, Australia, and Singapore, long-time allies of the US, worked together to increase economic growth through trade liberalization. Building closer ties with friendly countries will benefit trade negotiations for liberalization in the next century. The United States must continue promoting its interests in the Asia-Pacific region through aggressive trade negotiations. Bilateral trade agreements can positively influence multilateral and regional trade talks by expanding common areas of agreement on trade disciplines. Trade and investment disputes between the United States and its allies can be resolved through these negotiations. Free trade agreements between the United States and Pacific Rim countries can effectively resolve trade disputes and enhance cooperation, ensuring mutually beneficial economic and political relations. Free trade agreements between the United States and Pacific Rim countries will enhance market access and help stabilize the bilateral trade balance, ensuring mutually beneficial economic and political relations. The United States aims to improve trade policy with eligible Pacific Rim countries. The United States aims to eliminate tariff and nontariff barriers through bilateral free trade agreements with Pacific Rim countries, addressing issues such as national treatment, foreign investment, intellectual property protection, and government measures. The United States aims to eliminate barriers such as discriminatory standards, government measures like price controls, and unfair trade activities through free trade agreements with Pacific Rim countries. SEC. 3. PRENEGOTIATION CONSULTATIONS. Within 60 days of enacting the Act, the President will consult with eligible Pacific Rim countries. If feasible, a ministerial meeting will be requested to discuss formal negotiations for a free trade agreement. The United States International Trade Commission will provide advice within 6 months after each ministerial meeting. Within 6 months of each ministerial meeting with eligible Pacific Rim countries, the US International Trade Commission will advise the President on the economic effects of providing duty-free treatment for their products on US industries and consumers. SEC. 4. MINISTERIAL MEETING RECOMMENDATIONS. The President recommends establishing a council of public and private sector officials to review trade practices, customs laws, economic data, and disputes for a free trade agreement. The council must issue a report on the bilateral relationship within 6 months of its establishment. The council will review trade practices, customs laws, economic data, and disputes for a free trade agreement. Within 6 months, a report on the overall bilateral relationship and prospects for a successful negotiation of a free trade agreement will be issued. The council will review trade practices, customs laws, economic data, and disputes for a free trade agreement. Within 6 months, a report on the overall bilateral relationship and prospects for a successful negotiation of a free trade agreement will be issued. Presidential determination on negotiating free trade agreements with eligible countries is required. The President must make a determination on the feasibility and desirability of starting formal negotiations for a free trade agreement with a Pacific Rim country within 6 months of receiving a report from a bilateral council. This determination will be based on advice from the Advisory Committee for Trade Policy Negotiations and the International Trade Commission. A report on this determination will be submitted to the Senate and House committees. The President must consider specific factors when determining the feasibility of establishing a free trade area with an eligible country, including membership in the World Trade Organization, interest in a bilateral agreement with the US, trade liberalization efforts, and alignment with US trade policy goals. The country has an open economy, aligns with US trade policy objectives, actively participates in WTO meetings, and works to eliminate export and local content requirements while seeking harmonization of standards. The organization is focused on eliminating trade barriers, harmonizing standards, increasing economic opportunities for small- and medium-sized businesses, and resolving trade disputes with the United States. The United States aims to resolve trade disputes constructively with countries benefiting from improved dispute settlement mechanisms and enhanced market access by eliminating trade barriers. The President must consult regularly with specific Congressional committees regarding the implementation of the Act. The Act defines eligible Pacific Rim countries as WTO members and APEC economies.
